25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$5$"TL;DR; I was prescribed 10mg daily of this medication to counteract moderate anxiety. But it has helped with panic attacks as well. It was effective almost from day one and I recommend it to others.

column1: The Bad: I got nausea the first 2 days
column2: headaches for about a week
column3: soft stools for about 3 weeks and a small loss in libido.

column1: The Good: I noticed a real difference within days of taking the medication. I'm skeptical that it was a placebo effect because they say it shouldn't have full effect till 2-4 weeks
column2: however
column3: I don't care and I'll take what I can get even if it was a placebo effect. I used to have panic attacks
column4: and general anxiety to many things. I'd hold to things for days and I'd generally be down
column5: even though I was convinced what I had was just a ""regular amount of stress"". Right away
column6: I noticed I didn't have rash and abrupt reactions to things
column7: things rolled off me a lot easier and I approached everything in life more calmly. I've had more focus at work
column8: I'm able to concentrate better and I'm more engaged with family and my kids. "

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$In my experience Lexapro is the only medication that has helped me manage depression
column3: panic disorder and BMT Migraines.  Prior
column4: I've been on a number of widely prescribed medication to treat those conditions without seeing any benefits and having my symptoms worsen. Once I started on Lexapro

column9: I'd warn about switching from brand name to generic escitalopram. In my case
column10: it caused quick return of debilitating mood changes.  I have to take twice the dose of escitalopram to get the benefit of single dose of Lexapro.

208$Anxiousness associated with Depression$12/13/2018 5:42:02 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I have had anxiety off and on for years, but it was always controllable. However, it became more and more progressive over the past few months where my anxiety would trigger full blown panic attacks. One day, I woke up feeling extremely anxious and it did not go away all day. The anxiety progressed so fast where I had episodes of trembling throughout the day, completely lost my appetite, and would even wake up in the middle of the night with extreme anxiety. the anxiety took over and It was all I could think about. It became so debilitating, just trying to go to the store was the hardest task in the world and I was terrified to do so. My anxiety triggered deep depression. I am usually very full of energy, work out, and happy. I have a full time job, and two young kids so I knew I had to see a doctor and get things figured out. I was diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder and Depression. I am not one to take medicine and am usually scared to do so, but anything was worth a try at this point. I was prescribed 10mg of Lexapro and within a week, felt a difference. It has been 2.5 weeks now, and I feel like myself again and like I have my life back. The medicine helped with my anxiety first, so I still felt my depression until about the second week. I personally haven't experienced any crazy side effects yet, and feel a headache or a little weight gain (if that does happen) is way better than the extreme anxiety and depression I was battling. My Dr.'s goal is to slowly lower my dose after a few months until I am good to be completely off it, as she believes my diagnosis is situational. This medicine truly saved me and gave me my life back. You just have to stick with it!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$5$"My anxiety hit a high in my mid 20s & went from every once in a while to a constant drowning feeling of anxiety. When it became paralyzing
column3: I started therapy. After 4 months of therapy & being against medication

column1: For the first couple of months as I increased the dosage
column2: I became extremely paranoid that I was going to become suicidal. The weird part was that I had never even thought about this before and never experienced symptoms of depression. I started to learn through therapy that it stemmed from my fear of losing control of my anxiety and myself and the worst case scenario of that would be killing myself.

column1: I then became extremely motivated to become the best version of myself that I could be. With more therapy
column2: daily mental exercises
column3: physical exercise and A LOT of hard work... I was able to shake the paranoid thoughts and have never appreciated life more than I do now. Lexapro helped with the physical symptoms but if you suffer from anxiety and panic disorder you still need therapy. The medication is just one part of the process. But with all of the hard work and a daily pep talk in the mirror

column1: I see life different & I am so grateful for the little things because I once couldn't enjoy them because of my anxiety and physical sickness. For those who are suffering from anxiety

column2: 19-24 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$1$4$"So I became depressed after a traumatic death of my only sibling. I'm not a fan of taking drugs to ""fix"" a symptom (I consider depression to be a symptom of a larger problem) but I was so behind in everything and I needed to get myself up to speed again so my doctor prescribed 10mg of Lexapro and told me to take it at night. It was horrible. The first night
column3: I took the drug and went to sleep. About an hour later
column4: I woke up and threw up violently then proceeded to have wave after wave of panic attacks for the next 5-6 hours. The next night
column5: I took the drug and told myself that the first night was probably just my body adjusting to the new medication and that I would be fine and it wouldn't happen again. But it happened again. And again. And again. I had constant panic attacks for about 2 weeks before I just stopped taking the drug. I couldn't handle it. I wasn't sleeping at all. And my doctor had the nerve to tell me that I caused the panic attacks - but I wasn't causing them - I'm well versed in panic attacks and I know when I'm causing them and when they just happen. I don't recommend just stopping the drug like I did because that could REALLY MESS YOU UP but I made sure I was watched for a couple days after I stopped taking it in case something happened. The antidepressant part actually did work - I felt a lot better and that ""heavy cloud"" feeling was gone but I just couldn't handle the panic attacks so I decided to deal with the depression on my own and it took longer than I wanted but it's gone now and I didn't ever go back on a drug to do it. "

column1: 495$Depression$8/21/2013 10:10:58 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$1$3$"I was given Lexapro when I was 14 years old. I stopped taking it when I was 23. Coming off of this medication was one of the hardest things I ever did
column2: but I am a much better person for it. Most people don't need to be on these types of pills
column3: and some people do. You are strong enough to get off this medication and change the things in your life that are causing you to take it in the first place. I recently spent a month in the ICU of a hospital where I had a sudden perforated gastric ulcer which no doctors could figure out what caused. I never had problems with acid in my stomach or abdominal pain or any other symptom of an ulcer until it perforated and it was the most excruciating pain I have ever felt. After doing research
column4: I found out that the cause of my perforated ulcer was most likely the Lexapro paired with NSAID pain relievers. These medications cause more harm than is worth making you ""happy"". I strongly advise not taking these types of anti-depressants unless it is your absolute last resort. Coming off Lexapro was a horrible experience
column5: with all the withdrawal symptoms but putting those chemicals in my body was not worth it. It will take you a while to feel like a brand new person but in the end it is all worth it."

column1:
565$Depression$3/25/2013 3:31:36 PM$Reviewer: Les, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$I have suffered from major depression and anxiety for over two decades.  Lexapro is the best of all the a/ds I've taken.  I've taken many.  I think Lexapro is the purest of the SSRIs. Its been clean and effective.  By clean, I mean the initial side effect was minor: stomach upset for 2 or 3 days.  I think that's a good start compared to the side effects of most a/ds.  I started feeling noticeably better in two weeks.  I'm now completing the first month and I don't think I'm done improving.  This medication allows me to function normally. No more black hole sadness, most anxiety gone, no feelings of baseless guilt, worthlessness, etc.  Little things don't freeze me into inaction. I'm starting to enjoy life again.  I even laugh now and then.  Lexapro has really helped-- but I still have to put my best foot forward each day to cognitively add to the chemical boost of Lexapro. Only concern now:  No ejaculation.  I can still get an erection with the help of an e.d. med. I'm holding out a slim hope that with time my body will adjust and I'll return somewhere close to normal.  For now, though, feeling better is the most important aspect of my life.  So far, so good.

583$Depression$2/25/2013 3:00:25 PM$Reviewer:  (Patient) $1$1$1$The manufacturers who market this drug have gotten in trouble for unethical marketing practices. This is the most potent of the SSRIs inhibiting serotonin re-uptake far more than other SSRIs. This causes a higher incidence of serotonin syndrome with this drug. It also causes increased side effects like aggression, apathy, and sexual dysfunction. Overall this drug is not healthy. Celexa is a far better alternative to Lexapro, which is far too potent.

594$Depression$2/7/2013 10:25:32 PM$Reviewer: Not blue sue, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$I took this medication every night (10-15 mgs) for almost 10 years for prolonged low grade depression. In order to alleviate the lethagy, I was also taking bupropion in the morning (300 mg) in the morning.  This worked very well for me.  I recently decided it was time to try to live without the drugs.  I was struggling with mood swings but they were not long lasting and I thought I would level out.  However, when superstorm Sandy hit and my house was badly damaged, I found that I was in a depression.  When I went back on them, my prescription drug plan filled it with the generic version and this caused severe reflux (heartburn), headaches and was not as effective in lifting the depression.  I had it refilled with the original Lexapro and all my side effects disappeared and I felt much better emotionally.  Since I am no longer working full time, I do not need the bupropion anymore as I do not need to function at that pace anymore.

column1: 749$Depression$4/8/2012 4:32:08 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year$3$2$3$I've had two major depressive episodes and decided to take Lexapro for the last one. I have also tried Zoloft and Prozac in the past and generally do not take medication between episodes. Lexapro worked quickly and well--I felt improvements within a week and completely recovered after about two months. It's clearly effective. I do have some complaints
column2: however: 1. First and foremost
column3: Lexapro has a nasty withdrawal. I have never had a problem coming off SSRIs in the past but had significant trouble with this one. Tons of ""brain zaps
column4: irritability
column5: mood swings
column6: etc. It's a real pain to taper off. Make sure to do it very carefully
column7: slowly
column8: and under supervision. If you taper off too quickly
column9: you could end up depressed all over again. 2. Sexual side effects were the worst of any SSRI I've taken. In my case
column10: much lower libido and difficulty reaching orgasm. Most SSRIs have these extremely unfortunate side effects
column11: but this one gave me the most trouble. 3. Dosing is a bit awkward. 10mg didn't work quite well enough for me and 20mg worked but made me feel like a spaced-out zombie. I was too frustrated by the end to try 15
column12: admittedly
column13: but there isn't much room for finding an ideal dosage. 4. Extremely expensive if insurance doesn't cover it. It's set to go generic this year
column14: although I don't have the latest news on this. Every medication works different for everybody
column15: and this was only my experience. I would first and foremost say that if you feel depressed or anxious
column16: make sure you see a therapist and make appropriate lifestyle changes. If you need an antidepressant
column18: works for me at the minimal dose (20mg) and no withdrawal. Maybe this will work for you
column19: but I won't be taking it again."

4-	 Unbeknown to us  due to the absence of any discussion
column2: pamphlet
column3: ect. I was launched into state of mania shortly after discontinuing Lexapro medication.

column1: 5-	On August 3rd I submitted my resignation to my employer after 21 year 6 months of service with a fictitious place of employment going forward as I was in a manic state.
6-	During the remainder of time I acted in words only (email) in a very hostile manner to many layers of upper management essentially black balling myself.

7-	Over the month of August I found myself reacting in a hostile manner with three individuals in public with no reason and only due to the manic state I incurred from Lexapro. None of these encounters turned physical.
8-	I entered into a sales agreement for 150k to acquire a new boat. Grandiose spending.
9-	After the surrender of my Company provided car on August 29th I proceeded to purchase a new BMW lease car (500.00 per month) without an income. Grandiose spending.
10-	This manic state persisted until end of October where a very deep depression ensued.

In trying to recollect this occurrence I have found the FDA issued materials in regard to consuming Lexapro. None of the items within this material were at any  point ever outlined of discussed with me. None of the screening questions for this medication were ever discus"

Not long after taking it, my depression got worse. I turned to being suicidal. It also changed my sex drive to non existent. I was in my early 20's and I knew this wasn't normal. After the last and final time of attempting suicide, I finally talked to my doctor about it and she quickly took me off the lexapro. Since then, I have done better. I have personally decided to deal with my disorders without medication, which has been rough but lexapro has scared me into this decision. My 13 year old suffers from manic depression and ADHD. They are also considering that he may be bipolar. His doctor is switching him from zoloft and vyvance to lexapro and adderall. column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"I resisted taking medication at first and the stress of adopting two older kids finally got to me. I started on 10mg and felt spacey so dropped to 5mg. I have been at this dose for 2.5 years. I have been pleasantly surprised at the result - I know I am ""on"" something but it does not get in the way of my daily activity. I am able to let go of hostile situations more easily. I am able to ""choose my battles"" easier. It gives me a bit of a pause button so I am not so quick to become overwhelmed
column3: sad
column4: upset
column5: angry. I still do feel these emotions
column6: just have more control of them. I once forgot my medication on a week long trip and the withdrawal was tolerable
column7: but I would not recommend it! Several times throughout the day I would get some flashes behind my eyes and the world would seem to vibrate for a few seconds
column8: then it would pass. As far as starting the drug or changing the dose
column9: ""they"" say that the drug takes 2 weeks to take effect. Maybe in most patients but not this one! No kidding
column10: I increase my dosage to 10mg and I feel it within hours. Now I increase my dose to 10mg for a few days around my cycle and it helps with the severe PMS/PMDD I experience. Maybe all in my head? I chart my cycle and there are many more PMS-induced arguments when I don't take the increased dose! The only bummer I can tell is low libido. Yeah
column11: BUMMER. Well
column12: the price of the drug is another bummer. As a cost savings I tried something similar - a generic called citalopram - it was AWFUL! It made me feel more than spacey - very messed up and more emotional. Good luck!"

column1: I stopped Lexapro in 2008 and experienced some withdrawl symptoms

column1: I recently went on Lexapro again in 2010 for anxiety and depression and the return of physical symptoms (thought I was having a heart attack
column2: but it was anxiety).  Upon starting Lexapro again
column3: I didn't have any vivid dreams but my physical symptoms went away.

column2: while the physical symptoms are gone
column3: my mood is rather neutral
column4: rather than happy or sad.  Also

column2: while some of the side effects annoying and bothersome

1269$Depression$10/10/2010 10:56:38 PM$Reviewer: Sadie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$4$5$I was diagnosed last winter with depression and social anxiety. I am also an alcoholic. My Dr wanted me to start with 5 mg and after a few weeks move up to 10. At first it was great but when I went up to 10 mg I had the side effects of sweating at night, vivid dreams and heavy menstrual periods. I felt zoned out too. I even had a major panic attack so I stopped taking it. Well the feelings of anxiety and despair came creeping back and I started drinking again. A few months ago I decided to quit drinking for good and I started 5 mg of Lex again. No symptoms this time! After a month I went up to 10 mg and still no side effects! I feel great.. no social anxiety! I am finally able to live, for myself and my children. And I am proud to say that I am 3 months sober and I believe the Lexapro has helped. The only downside is that I have heard the withdrawals are terrible. Someday I hope to be able to wean off of the meds but for now I am enjoying life again!

1291$Depression$9/16/2010 5:30:53 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$1$5$I took this med for about 3 1/2 years in varying doses according to my doctor's recommendation.  I gained about 30 pounds over that time period.  I finally decided to go off of it, because of the weight gain, it was not helping at all, and it was in fact making things worse.  I weaned myself off slowly.  The withdrawal effects ARE TERRIBLE.  Weird head 'zapping', dizziness, nausea...I could go on and on.  After almost 3 weeks off of Lexapro, I am starting to feel normal again, and have lost 11 pounds.  I would NOT recommend taking this drug.  The side effects while on the drug, as well as the withdrawal symptoms, made taking Lexapro a bad experience.  I am sad I wasted over 3 years of my life on this medication.

25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I took Lexapro (10mg daily) for almost 2 years.  It helped me control my depression and anxiety.  I knew that I had to ween off this medication slowly; I had taken other SSRIs in the past (Paxil
column3: Zoloft) and it is NOT a good idea to stop all at once
column4: you need a plan to ween off these meds.  I started to ween myself off and had terrible side affects - dizziness
column5: a strange head zapping feeling and increased anxiety.  I decided to stay on Lexapro awhile longer as I was busy with work and travel for my job and couldn't deal with a dizzy head.  A few months ago
column6: I slowly started to ween off again.  My doctor told me to cut the pill in half and take 5mg each day
column7: then after 1 week take 5mg every other day
column8: then every 2 days.  I took it even slower and took 5mg every other day for 1 month until I felt I was ready to stop completely.  I had the same side affects - dizzy head
column9: zapping feeling in my brain
column10: weird body aches.  I stuck with my plan and after 2 weeks
column11: the side affects completely disappeared and I felt completely normal.  I have not had any issues since.  My advice is to ween off slowly and stick it out if you have some mild side affects from withdrawl
column12: because they will go away.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver) $3$3$3$please be aware of side effects of any med u take. be proactive in your care. For three years my mother suffered from a fever of unknown origin. Tylenol
column3: ibuprofin nothing could brak the fever. i took her to multiple doctors specialists. and talked her into several procedures including bone marrow biopsies and polyp removal in her sinuses to try and get rid of this debilitating fever
column4: malaise
column5: fatigue and weakness.she lost 30 punds and nearly died of dehydration.After the 20th dr said he coulnt help and she told me she was ready to pass and couldnt live like this anymore i looked lexapro up in a drug book and the symptoms she had were listed. she stopped taking lexapro and the fevers and other symptoms went away. no dr bothered to look up side effects of this med and my mother almost left us. this is not a common side effect. lexapro was the miracle drug for my own depression
column6: i wouldnt be here now without it. just please be aware of what you are taking and possible side effects. we cant leave it all to the drs we must be our own advocates in our healthcare.  Lexapro is an effective treatment for most people. This message is out there in case anyone is suffering like my mother did and is searching for answers because the drs have let them down.

column1: I find that lexapro works better for me when I take it around the same time every day after I've eaten usually around 9:30am after breakfast. Lexapro will make you nauseated if you do not eat before taking. But as for not sleeping or gaining weight as mentioned in other reviews I have actually lost weight because I do more in the day
column2: I don't go home and just sit on the couch any more after work. This is the benefit of taking this medicine early in the morning I accomplish more during the day and when I go to bed I'm naturally tired and fall asleep. I don't plan on being on this medicine for very long but it is working for me when I'm needing it the most."

column1: Don't be scared the first time you see a reviewer mention weight gain or decreased libido.  It's more important that you get to feeling better and you can deal with those things later.
I've had depression for 30 years and Prozac 20mg worked for me up until I hit 50. Perhaps it was because I'm pre-menopausal or because I'd taken the same drug
column2: at the same dose for so many years.  I went to the doctor and tried several other drugs. At first
column3: I wasn't satisfied with any of them
column4: so I got on Effexor XR.  Wow!  Please read about the withdrawl symptoms when going off of Effexor
column5: because they are severe. Try all the other meds first. Something will work for you.

column2: I'm going back on Lexapro.  I don't think I gave it enough of a chance and it was working pretty well for me. Be patient and don't try to change meds or get off of something without a doctor's advice.  Been there
column3: done that
column4: and it was terrible.  I believe that Lexapro is a wonderful drug. It is sure the best I've tried so far. I believe our bodies get used to something and it finally stops working. That's what happened to me with Prozac
column5: although it was my wonder drug for 20+ years. I'm going to ask my doctor if perhaps I should rotate between Lexapro and Prozac every few years. That may be the answer for me.

column2: but you have to be patient. Also exercise

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$Lexapro has made significant positive impact on my and my family's life. column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$3$5$"A lot of these reviews are suspicious so I decided to write one.

column1: I've been taking Lexapro for over 4 years now
column2: I originally started at 10mg
column3: once per day
column4: I shortened my dose to half a pill every other day due to severe anger problems while taking this medication. I can say it definitely helps with depression
column5: however for me it was very ineffective at helping with OCD issues -- I still have my routines
column6: merely in spurts now.

column1: I do not recommend this medication to anyone unless all other medications for lighter symptoms fail. This drug is very powerful and should not be taken simply because you had a bad day at work
column2: etc. I can vouch for anger issues associated with taking this medication daily
column3: as well as bi-polar behavior and loss of mental focus
column4: lack of feeling real/alive mentally & visually
column5: etc.

column1: I've tried kicking this medication and it is not difficult to get off of
column2: very few withdrawals -- however I suggest cutting the dose gradually rather than going cold turkey.

column1: This medication does not seem to conflict with Propranolol.
Side effects I have experienced are dry mouth
column2: constipation
column3: jittery eyes and erection problems but they are tolerable in comparison to depression.

column2: at least $90 without insurance.
make sure it works for you and you feel it helps
column3: otherwise find one that actually helps you and do not force yourself to adapt mentally to it."

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$1$5$I took Lexapro for 3 months ans it worked great fro the first month.  Then after I noticed I was like it was not working well almost kept thinking that it was a bad batch of Lexapro.  Then I started to get really depressed like it would work one day and not the next.  Then a little bit more than the last 2 weeks I took it I started to get suicidial thoughts kept popping in my head just randomly more when I was by myself but the even when I would be at work and I would just start thinking about it.  Just before I quit and got onto something else I almost commited suicide and I have never had problems like that before so just be very careful and let your doctor know of any little change.  If I would have had a gun I would be not telling anyone who is reading this now.  Good Luck.

column1: 2119$Depression$8/20/2009 11:09:31 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $2$1$3$"I was prescribed Lexapro to treat my depression
column2: and was only on the drug for one week. During that week
column3: my energy level dropped significantly
column4: I could barely stay awake throughout the day and my brain was in a complete fog. I was spaced out and loopy and felt exhausted. It didn't matter whether I took it in the morning or at night
column5: with our without food
column6: the results were the same. I could barely function through a work day
column7: and I probably shouldn't have been driving a car in this state. I didn't cry or feel depressed during the week
column8: but I can't say that I felt much of anything
column9: except strange. I have been off it for 24 hours now
column10: and the difference is amazing. I have my energy back
column11: I'm not loopy and I'm not physically exhausted. I can focus on work tasks again. My doctor has prescribed Cymbalta as the next drug for me to try for treating the depression
column12: which I have not started yet.

column1: I read many positive reviews about Lexapro
column2: and I guess the point of me writing this review is so that people can see that in some cases
column3: this drug is clearly not for everyone. And if you are immediately experiencing some of the less common side effects
column4: talk to your doctor immediately."

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$1$5$"WARNING. Lexapro has been know to unmask bipolar that would otherwise remain hidden. column3: I started to feel too good and started displaying signs of hypomania (high part of bipolar). This effected every relationship
column4: both personal and professional in my life
column5: but I didn't care at the time and I stayed on the medication. After I realized that Lexapro had uncovered a hidden hypomania activity
column6: I weened off of it
column7: taking 5MG a day for two weeks then 5MG everyother day. After I was off Lexapro for a month
column8: I returned to major depression that was way worse than the original episode. The good feelings associated with Lexapro are artifical and it commonly will ""unmask"" bipolar activities. I was never aware of this risk and no doctor talked about it untill it was too late. Use with caution

55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$5$"I suffer from mild depression.  I don't contemplate suicide but am depressed a lot
column3: seemingly without reason.  Seven months ago my doctor prescribed

column1: Lexapro so I tried the 10mg dose.  It took a week or two to feel a change but it definitely works for me.  My wife tells me I'm a lot easier to live with and frankly I feel more comfortable most of the time.  I'm certainly much less depressed than before.  I recommend it for those that reap its benefits.  Like any drug
column2: it's probably not for everyone.  However there are some negative considerations as well.  It's harder to wake up in the morning.  I take naps when I can.  Sometimes I fall asleep reading a book
column3: where I never used to.  Sexual desire is down but not gone.  I don't feel it has inhibited an erection but sometimes reaching orgasm can be difficult.  I guess that's why they make Viagra.  Another thing to consider is
column4: don't miss a dose.  I failed to take it one morning and noticed I was a bit more grouchy than usual that day.  I took it the following day and was so spaced out at work that I hope I never forget to take it again.  I was forgetting people's names I had known for a while.  Familiar things were unfamiliar. 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I've been on Lexapro for a year and have been very pleased with the results.  Take it for depression/anxiety combo.  Started out on Lorazepam for anxiety attacks

column11: nausea

column14: figuring the side effects would go away once my body adjusted to the medication.  I also switched to taking the medication at night right before I went to bed instead of in the morning
column15: so any side effects would occur while I was sleeping and I didn't feel them as much.  Thankfully making that switch did the trick and as far as I know the side effect went away after the first week or so.  Give it time if you're just starting or thinking about starting.

2543$Depression$4/11/2009 9:27:59 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I was diagnosed with Depression/General Anxiety Disorder. I was having panic attacks and couldn't finish a thought yet would lay awake at night and stress all day about anything and everything. I was prescribed 10 mg at first and took that for about a month. After having another awful panic attack in my sleep I asked the doctor to up the dosage. Now I have been taking 20mg for over 2 years and it does wonders for me. I am more even-tempered and don't have the anxiety/panic attacks. Sometimes I still struggle with stressing about things but not like I did before. I can finish a thought and think clearly. It has improved my memory (I have a really bad memory-some short term and long term)and I am able to function much better daily. I did have sexual side effects for a long while but after so long those seemed to dissolve as well. I wish I could tell everyone who needs help about this and how it has helped me. There's nothing more relieving than to be able to function everyday on a normal basis. I would recomment atleast trying this medication.

column1: 2701$Depression$2/19/2009 1:56:35 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$1$"DISCONTINUING LEXAPRO IS HELL.
Most doctors do not warn patients about SSRI DISCONTINUATION SYNDROME
column2: so please research this before deciding that Lexapro is right for you.

column1: Lexapro was fairly effective at easing my depression
column2: but every time I missed a dose
column3: I felt sick.  Because of this
column4: and the sexual side effects (complete inability to orgasm
column5: no arousal during sex
column6: no interest in sex)
column7: I decided to switch to Wellbutrin
column8: and let me tell you
column9: DISCONTINUING LEXAPRO IS HELL.  PLEASE
column10: please before taking Lexapro
column11: look up SSRI Discontinuation Syndrome on Wikipedia. It has been over a month since I finally tapered off Lexapro
column12: and I have felt sick the whole time.  It's like having the flu every day but it doesn't go away
column13: and the feeling of being ""zapped"" every few minutes is VERY disconcerting.  I am only JUST starting to feel better
column14: however I still get major headaches every day
column15: I feel like I have a low-grade fever and my body still hurts most of the time.

column2: DO NOT QUIT COLD TURKEY. TAPER OFF VERY SLOWLY to lessen the very unpleasant effects of discontinuing it.  My doctor had me taking 50mg/day
column3: which sounds like a lot
column4: but it took that much to be effective for me. But nobody warned me that I would have to take it the rest of my life or suffer the misery of discontinuing it.

column1: Lexapro can be a very effective medication
column2: and the benefits of taking it can outweigh the problems it may cause
column3: so do the research and make an educated decision based upon your personal needs.

column1: Keep in mind that WebMD is sponsored by pharmaceutical companies
column2: so you probably won't find anything about SSRI Discontinuation Syndrome here unless you are reading what patients have submitted.

column1: Please research carefully and thoroughly so that you understand exactly what you are getting into if you do decide to take Lexapro.  "

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $4$4$4$"To the poster below seeking withdrawal advice:

column1: I took Lexapro for 11 years after the death of my son and husband.  Got tired of taking it and AMA
column2: I weaned myself off it a little tiny bit at a time.  I actually shaved down the tablet over 4 months until there was nothing left.  Side effects were ""brain freeze""
column3: delayed vision
column4: nausea
column5: headache
column6: feeling like I was falling backwards
column7: and other minor ones.  I put my friends and employer on notice and they helped out a lot.  If you decide to withdraw
column8: do it very
column9: very slowly and watch for the side effects.  They disappear over time.  I've been off 2 years now and I'm fine.  I cry but I prefer that to not feeling anything. On the other hand
column10: Lexapro helped me get through the roughest thing I'll ever experience.  I could not have done it without help and Lexapro stabilized me enough that outside professional help was possible."

column2: 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"Lexapro was added to Welbutrin XL 3 years ago for my depression.  The two medicines together have made me feel ""normal"" again.  "

column1: The main reason I am writing this is that I experienced strong anxiety
column2: bordering on panic attacks
column3: for the first couple of days that I was taking the drug.  My doctor was skeptical that this was possible so quickly - one of the main reasons he prescribed Lexapro specifically was due to the relatively low incidence of major side effects.

column1: I just want to make sure that anyone else who experiences a similar reaction initially knows that it is not just them.  The major anxiety went away for me after a couple of days.  I have had some degree of a lot of the side effects listed (dry mouth
column2: stomach issues
column3: some decrease in sex drive
column4: etc.) but they have dissipated over time.

column2: counseling
column3: and some changes that I made in my life
column4: I have been able to go from being pretty depressed most of the time (to the degree of having borderline suicidal thoughts) to feeling fairly close to normal.

column1: So just some encouragement that though some people may have more difficulty getting started on the drug than they are led to expect
column2: it has been worth it in my experience."

column1: 3561$Depression$3/28/2008 10:33:50 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$3$4$Was on it for 3+ years and decided with my doc to change meds because my sex drive was NONEXISTENT and other meds had become available that had fewer sexual side effects - We weaned me down VERY slowly - Literally over a month's time or more - Did the last .25mg for 2 weeks and then stopped - Felt weird at first and then exactly 10-14 days after my last dose I crashed - We had had a snowstorm the night before and all the dr.'s offices in town were closed - I wasn't suicidal
column2: per se
column3: but I definitely had a concious understanding of how people can be - Scared me very badly and I went to the emergency room immediately - The psych on call ended up working for the same place where I went for therapy sessions so I started seeing him and everything went very well after that - So my primary opinion is that you should be VERY VERY careful when you are going off of it

column1: 3562$Depression$3/27/2008 11:12:57 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$I only took Lexapro for one day
column2: but my symptoms were so outrageous that I know it's not for me. One of the symptoms that I saw no one else listed was difficulty breathing. When I had been sitting for a long period of time and got up to walk around
column3: my heart would beat a lot faster and I couldn't breathe very well. After a couple of hours
column4: I became very tense to the point where my lower back began aching. Near the end of the day
column5: I was so awake I couldn't sleep ALL night
column6: even after I took a sleeping pill. Lexapro may work wonders for some people
column7: but I just felt like I took a stimulant rather than an SSRI.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I was on another a.d. for years and it was fine but I am always seeking something better.  YOU CANNOT TAKE THIS AT NIGHT if you have anxiety.  Yes

column4: a bonus for me is I have no appetite.  I'm only 50 lbs overweight and I am trying to lose weight but am an emotional eater.  So this has helped.  I just started it 3 weeks ago at 10mg

35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$1$1$This drug does have side effects that can be quite difficult for some.  I had frequent headaches and dizziness.  The side effects way out did any minor benefits of the drug. Coming off of the drug was even more problematic.  It was horrid.  I was disconnected and dizzy constantly.  I almost passed out on numerous occasions.  I felt sick constantly.  I couldn't focus on anything.  It was horrible.  Even more troubling was having two doctors tell me that they had never heard of such a thing from Lexapro while my pharmacist told me the opposite.  All the research I had done listed all of the symptoms I was having and then some in coming off of the medication. I know two additionall people taking the medication that have had nothing but problems while on it and coming off of it.  I have since switched to a much more effective remedy with no side effects-5-HTP.  I have never felt better and have had absolutely no problems with taking 5-HTP.

Overall I am doing much better considering I was in the hospital 3 weeks ago and am now at home (though going to group therapy daily on short term disability).  One bad side effect of Lexapro for me (being a male) is sexual dysfunction.  But
column8: from what I read online
column9: that is a ""common and known"" issue.  To describe the problem in ""kind words""... let's just say the bomber can take off and fly the mission

column11: but I tried to be polite about it.  I hope the doctor slowly tapers my dosage back and that issue gradually goes away.  But
column12: for now

I told my doctor I wasn't sleeping well and was somewhat unhappy with what happened to me time after having 2 kids close together. I specifically said I didn't want to gain weight and I enjoyed my sex life and didn't want any interference.  Unfortunately
column3: I let him talk me into it and continued with it til now.  I have since gained at least 20 lbs. and have a harder time orgasming. The weight gain has not helped my self confidence either.  I started weening myself off the meds slowly and will try to deal with the side effects - dizziness
column4: nausea
column5: memory issues both on and getting off meds.  I have since been able to join a gym which my kids also enjoy going to.  That is how I used to be - very active.  I just had to be patient until my kids were a little older to allow more time for me.  Again
column6: I should of listened to my instinct
column7: not cover up everyday issues of a new mom with medication.  Some people need extra help with all kinds of issues.  I just think my doctor was quick with prescribing without understanding my background.  Too quick to line the pockets of drug companies.  There are way too many people on meds that might really not need it.  I am not discounting some real mental issues that need meds.  I used to work with a psychiatrist and do believe many do need meds.  I just would recommend investigating the meds and getting a couple of opinions if possible.  I just cannot wait to get off this med.  Good luck to those of you on it.

25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$1$5$The doctors don't tell you this
column3: or maybe most of them don't know.  I took Lexapro for a couple of years to deal with depression from a stressful job/condescending boss.  It did work
column4: but when I stopped taking it I started getting brain jolts
column5: zaps in my mouth
column6: dizziness
column7: vertigo type feeling when I would move my eyeballs
column8: spinning when I would move my eyeballs
column9: and I also had headaches.  It is very hard to explain the symptoms
column10: but you know it when you are dealing with it.  I was absolutely miserable.  I didn't know what it was from and ended up at many doctor's offices thinking I had a brain tumor
column11: multiple sclerosis
column12: you name it.  They gave me an MRI of my brain
column13: lots of tests
column14: you name it.  Finally I did some of my own research on the internet and found that there a LOTS of other people that were going through the same thing.  I just had to type in the right thing in google and there it was.  There were so many people with the same problem
column15: not only from Lexapro but other anti-depressants as well.  You would think doctors would know!These horrible things finally went away after about 6 months of torture.  I don't wish what I went through upon anybody.  I guess if you are never planning on getting off the meds then you are ok
column16: but if it's just a temporary thing then I would recondisder.  The withdrawl symptoms are just too much.  I was also suicidal during the withdrawl.  It is out of my system now and I am clean of anything and feel much better.  If only one person reads this and listens to me it will be worth it to save them from something like this.

4147$Depression$10/28/2007 4:32:41 PM$Reviewer: Bud, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$I have been taking antidepressants since 1970 and recently came to believe that my depression has been caused by anxiety--worrying constantly sends me into depression.  Lexapro is the first antidepressant (others:elavil, norpramin, prozac, wellbutrin) which has effectively suppressed my anxiety.  I have not felt much, what I might call, joy.  But I have not been deeply depressed for over 3 1/2 months.  I've never gone more than 4 months without sinking into a dark tunnel.  The next month will be crititical, and I hope that I can follow up on these remarks.

I have noticed no side effects whatsoever and am amazed at how much better I feel.
4154$Depression$10/27/2007 11:28:07 PM$Reviewer: Cindy B, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Ive been taking this medication for the last 4 years and I feel that I can't live without it
4157$Depression$10/27/2007 1:59:29 AM$Reviewer: Melodious, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months$4$1$4$ I was on this drug for about 6 weeks and noticed a very positive change in my mood as well as less panic attacks with anxiety.  However, right about the six week mark, I woke one morning to swelling in my hands and feet three times the normal size.  I could not fit into my shoes.  Also, my limbs ached terribly like I have never experienced before.  My feet hurt to walk on our hardwood floor, I could not hold a cup of coffee because my fingers ached so badly and I was bedridden for about 3 days because it was too painful to move.  Bloodwork from my doctor revealed a very rare side effect from this drug.  I was terribly disappointed since I really felt this was working for me.  My doctor has given me samples of Effexor to try instead so hopefully this will work.
4158$Depression$10/26/2007 11:48:32 PM$Reviewer: Catpurrrson, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$This treatment has been mostly successful for me. I hardly ever cry no matter what the situation is and that has even included the death of my husband of 27 years.
4161$Depression$10/26/2007 2:54:43 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $1$1$5$My doctor put me on Lexapro during a difficult period of my life.  It caused me to have a flat affect as noticed by a friend who didn't know I was taking anything.  Also, I had an incredible weight gain of 30 pounds in about 6 months. I experienced a lack of sex drive and also the inability to have an orgasm.  My husband was away for eight months and I wasn't interested in having sex at all.  Everything returned to normal after I stopped taking it. Lastly, coming off of this drug was shear hell.  I was so sick even though I was reducing extremely slowly.  I experienced what felt like electric shocks in my brain quite frequently.  All I wanted to do was sleep because when I slept, I didn't feel anything.  It was horrible.  I vowed never to take anything again, but recently I was convinced by another doctor to try Wellbutrin.  So far so good.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$5$I feel it has helped me and I have been on it for over 2 years almost.  I had been on many other anti-depressants and this is the one that has helped my depression the most.  I am on 30 mg as of just a few days ago.  I was on 20 mg.  I have had no side effects with the medication.  And they are easy to take and do what they are supposed to do.  I was put on them originally by a Psychiatrist and also recommended by my own personl Physician (Internist) who I have 100% trust and faith in.  I can't say the same for the Psyhiatrist as he only saw me for 5 minute intervals and I was out the door.  My own personal Internist can do the same prescribing and spends a lot more time with me.  I will soon be seeing a new Psychiatrist as my Doctor feels I may need a mood stabilizer.  So I don't know with that being thrown into the mix (depending on what the Psychiatrist puts me on) how it will mix with the Lexapro.  My Doctor feels I may be Bi-polar and need a certain medication like Lithium.  But that is up to the Psychiatrist.  When I was on Cymbalta 30 mg I was fine but when the original Psychiatrist prescribed the 60 mg I broke out in hives and a rash all over my body.  My lower lip swelled up and my face some.  I was in agony with that rash off and on for months.  So anyone on Cymbalta beware as this is what happened to me.  I never had one bad side effect from Lexapro.  I know a lot of others on it and they haven't either.  Lexapro is my anti-depressant choice.  And believe me I have been on at least 10 different ones.  Thank you.  Diane L. column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$4$"I've used both citalopram and escitalopram on and off over the years. I was on a very high dose of citalopram (north of 40mg) and used that drug for two years.

column1: Anyone considering using any SSRI needs to assess the clinical need of their use and weigh this against the potential side effects because there are many. These drugs take forever to start working. Don't under any circumstances exceed the dose you're prescribed without your MD's guidance...You will go to a very dark place. These drugs need to build up in your system.

Once the citalopram took effect I felt the greatest I ever had in life...this in spite of the yawning and slight lethargy I experienced. Both drugs improved my concentration and I wake up feeling very alert. One other issue I had was that I relapsed when I tried to get off the citalopram and had to go back on it like less than a month after I discontinued.

With the citalopram I had a reduced sex drive - not so much with the escitalopram. One other thing I noticed was that the escitalopram reduces my desire to drink alcohol...It may be useful for people with addiction.

My only complaint is that I wish this stuff would just work faster...if you're really suffering those initial three weeks before the drug starts to work can be rough. Furthermore I need higher doses of this stuff and regular MDs (not psychiatrists) can only prescribe this medication up to 40mg. Basically it's a commitment if you want to use these things and they're bit of a hassle to get on and off."

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$"This worked for me within days. It doesn't make me tired at all. I built up a resistance in about 2 months that caused the doctor to increase the dose from 10 to 20 mg daily.

column1: The first time I took Lexapro I was also depressed. I stopped taking it after 1 month and it was a small dose. It made me less depressed so I would consider it to have worked.
I have never continued to take it once I started feeling ""normal"" again.
This time I continued taking it way beyond the point of my ""Normal"". It had a Manic effect on me as best as I can tell. I have never felt like that before.
I was getting a solid 4 hours of sleep a night and was able to get up in the morning a few hours ahead of schedule. I even felt good about my work and home environment.

I starting singing aloud for no reason. I couldn't stop talking to myself. I decided to make up some imaginary friends to entertain myself. I was unable to control my thougths without shutting down or giving it my full concentration. I got angry over nothing. I started thinking about killing myself. I became paranoid and stressed out over my living situation. I came very close to doing something that I really couldn't control. Very scary way to be
column2: not in control of your brain when you really need to be. I took risks that I wouldn't normally take. I went to the doctor and we both agreed to stop taking it right away.

I was taking prozac for depression. This works much better for me than Prozac and I didn't see any side effects other than going Manic. I think I should have stopped taking it once I hit my ""Normal"" like I did before."

712$Major Depressive Disorder$5/26/2012 9:31:10 AM$Reviewer: davepaul777, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$3$4$Since 1994 I've used nearly every anti-depressant out there even the old ones. I'm diagnosed with Schizoaffective disorder/depressive type and psychotic depression. I was going to have ECT but decided to give the meds one more chance. Lexapro seems to work the best. However, being male, I'm have severe erectile dysfunction and no libido. The doctor said this was most likely caused by the med. So it simply was a decision I had to make. I'm single and I'm more concerned with my illness and its treatment than being sexually active. My depression if not treated often caused severe delusions that would place me in a dangerous situation. However, after all this time including a commitment to a state hospital for over two years, I was always taught by my treatment providers that depression doesn't have to be treated by a only a drug. Finding a type of therapy such as CBT, DBT, or finding a support group is very beneficial. After years of seeing only my failures and problems my therapist made look back and remember good things and write them down. Self affirmations are nice also, and a little ice cream is good too.

column3: but this one gave me the most trouble.

column1: 3.  Dosing is a bit awkward.  10mg didn't work quite well enough for me and 20mg worked but made me feel like a spaced-out zombie.  I was too frustrated by the end to try 15
column2: admittedly
column3: but there isn't much room for finding an ideal dosage.

column1: 4.  Extremely expensive if insurance doesn't cover it.  It's set to go generic this year
column2: although I don't have the latest news on this.

column1: Every medication works different for everybody
column2: and this was only my experience.

column1: I would first and foremost say that if you feel depressed or anxious
column2: make sure you see a therapist and make appropriate lifestyle changes.
I would recommend Prozac--very cheap
column3: works for me at the minimal dose (20mg) and no withdrawal.

column1: Maybe this will work for you
column2: but I won't be taking it again."

I took the medication at 6pm after eating dinner and almost immediately felt ill. Went to bed to sleep through side effects, but woke up at 11pm to the room spinning. It was so bad I had to crawl to the bathroom to throw up. The entire next day I was sick to my stomach and unable to keep any food down, extreamly dizzy, and I had a horrible headache and could not take pain reliever due to drug interaction warning. I thought my body would get used to it by the next day, so again at 6pm I took the 10mg dose and tried to quickly go to bed. I had difficulty getting to sleep, staying asleep, and night sweats both nights. Woke up for work at 3am vomiting again, the same headache and inability to keep food down, but now I had developed shivers (teeth chattering) and excessive sweating. I feel like I have had the worst flu of my life for three days and am terrified to take another dose. That said, I was involved in several stressful situations at work that would normally have me totally anxious, and in a ball crying at home, if not at work, but i haven't broken down at all since taking it.

column1: 1985$Major Depressive Disorder$10/11/2009 12:12:01 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$I took tricyclics

column6: I might not be here anymore.) BACK TO SUBJECT: On Lexapro
column7: my anxiety was improved

column9: then upped to 20 mg when it seemed necessary. I will say that I have been more sleepy
column10: less energetic and have an increased appetite (translation: I gained 30 lbs. and I am a skinny person). I also have had increased problems with memory and concentration
column11: and have trouble finding words when I am speaking. I am not sure whether the focus/memory is due to the Lexapro or not. But it doesn't help those areas
column12: so I added Wellbutrin to the Lexapro for a time in order to see if focus/appetite/energy could be improved. I may still do that again at some point. My dr. said that using an SSRI for a long time can lead to less dopamine
column13: which you need for concentration
column14: energy and other things. For now
column15: I am switching to a drug that acts on more than one neurotransmitter (norepinephrine and serotinin) just like the combo of Wellbutrin and Lexapro to see if that helps with fatigue
column16: focus and memory. But I would not change a thing about my experience with Lexapro. It was the right drug for me at the time. If you are anxious and depressed
column17: it is an especially good option. Realize that you may have to revisit whether it's the best option from time to time.
